This article shows how to use Microsoft Entra credentials to create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI.

## Install the latest version of the Azure CLI

---

To use the Azure CLI to secure a SAS with Microsoft Entra credentials, first make sure that you have installed the latest version of Azure CLI. For more information about installing the Azure CLI, see [Install the Azure CLI](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/main/cli/azure/install-azure-cli).

To create a user delegation SAS using the Azure CLI, make sure that you have installed version 2.0.78 or later. To check your installed version, use the `az --version` command.

## Sign in with Microsoft Entra credentials

---

Sign in to the Azure CLI with your Microsoft Entra credentials. For more information, see [Sign in with the Azure CLI](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/main/cli/azure/authenticate-azure-cli).

## Assign permissions with Azure RBAC

---

metadata.title: Create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI

content:
/azure-docs/blob/main/cli/azure/authenticate-azure-cli).

## Assign permissions with Azure RBAC

---

To create a user delegation SAS from Azure PowerShell, the Microsoft Entra account used to sign in to Azure CLI must be assigned a role that includes the Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts/blobServices/generateUserDelegationKey action. This permission enables that Microsoft Entra account to request the *user delegation key*. The user delegation key is used to sign the user delegation SAS. The role providing the Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts/blobServices/generateUserDelegationKey action must be assigned at the level of the storage account, the resource group, or the subscription.

```
az role assignment create \
    --role "Storage Blob Data Contributor" \
    --assignee alpha-test-user@inventanalytics.com \
    --scope "/subscriptions/d1c7a815-cba1-458a-b08e-63c312a63ff5/resourceGroups/invent-test-rg/providers/Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts/inventtest"
```

metadata.title: Create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI

content:
c312a63ff5/resourceGroups/invent-test-rg/providers/Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts/inventtest"
```

## Use Microsoft Entra credentials to secure a SAS

---

When you create a user delegation SAS with the Azure CLI, the user delegation key that is used to sign the SAS is created for you implicitly. The start time and expiry time that you specify for the SAS are also used as the start time and expiry time for the user delegation key.

Because the maximum interval over which the user delegation key is valid is 7 days from the start date, you should specify an expiry time for the SAS that is within 7 days of the start time. The SAS is invalid after the user delegation key expires, so a SAS with an expiry time of greater than 7 days will still only be valid for 7 days.

metadata.title: Create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI

content:
ey expires, so a SAS with an expiry time of greater than 7 days will still only be valid for 7 days.

When creating a user delegation SAS, the `--auth-mode login` and `--as-user parameters` are required. Specify *login* for the `--auth-mode` parameter so that requests made to Azure Storage are authorized with your Microsoft Entra credentials. Specify the `--as-user` parameter to indicate that the SAS returned should be a user delegation SAS.

## Create a user delegation SAS for a container

---

To create a user delegation SAS for a container with the Azure CLI, call the [az storage container generate-sas](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/main/cli/azure/storage/container#az-storage-container-generate-sas) command.

metadata.title: Create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI

content:
oftDocs/azure-docs/blob/main/cli/azure/storage/container#az-storage-container-generate-sas) command.

Supported permissions for a user delegation SAS on a container include Add, Create, Delete, List, Read, and Write. Permissions can be specified singly or combined. For more information about these permissions, see [Create a user delegation SAS](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/main/rest/api/storageservices/create-user-delegation-sas).

The following example returns a user delegation SAS token for a container. Remember to replace the placeholder values in brackets with your own values:

```
az storage container generate-sas \
    --account-name <storage-account> \
    --name <container> \
    --permissions acdlrw \
    --expiry <date-time> \
    --auth-mode login \
    --https-only login \
    --as-user
```

metadata.title: Create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI

content:
dlrw \
    --expiry <date-time> \
    --auth-mode login \
    --https-only login \
    --as-user
```

noteThe SAS token returned by Blob Storage does not include the delimiter character ('?') for the URL query string. If you are appending the SAS token to a resource URL, remember to also append the delimiter character.

The SAS token returned by Blob Storage does not include the delimiter character ('?') for the URL query string. If you are appending the SAS token to a resource URL, remember to also append the delimiter character.

```
https://<storage-account>.blob.core.windows.net/<container-name>?<SAS>
```

## Example 1:

---

Storage Account: inventtest

Blob Container: input

Permissions:

- a: Add
- c: Create
- d: Delete
- l: List
- r: Read
- w: Write

Expiry Date: `2024-10-19`(YYYY-MM-DD)

Protocol: HTTPS only

---

metadata.title: Create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI

content:
ete
- l: List
- r: Read
- w: Write

Expiry Date: `2024-10-19`(YYYY-MM-DD)

Protocol: HTTPS only

---

```
az storage container generate-sas \
    --account-name inventtest \
    --name input \
    --permissions acdlrw \
    --expiry 2024-10-19 \
    --auth-mode login \
    --as-user \
    --https-only
```

Output (The user delegation SAS token returned will be similar to):

```
"se=2024-10-19&sp=racwdl&spr=https&sv=2022-11-02&sr=c&skoid=1949ec9b-2408-4586-be39-445a5e1592b6&sktid=5601ab2c-0ffb-47b0-8f77-dab790566623&skt=2024-10-18T05%3A30%3A25Z&ske=2024-10-19T00%3A00%3A00Z&sks=b&skv=2022-11-02&sig=xxxx
```

Delimiter: ‚Äú?‚Äù

## Revoke a user delegation SAS

metadata.title: Create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI

content:
d/1barD0Wt7AB2u7V6YtrmkZPEOr5ajuqk6NIb4UEJUJQQ/edit?usp=drive_link)

## Revoke a user delegation SAS

To revoke a user delegation SAS from the Azure CLI, call the [az storage account revoke-delegation-keys](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/main/cli/azure/storage/account#az-storage-account-revoke-delegation-keys) command. This command revokes all the user delegation keys associated with the specified storage account. Any shared access signatures associated with those keys are invalidated.

Remember to replace placeholder values in angle brackets with your own values:

```
az storage account revoke-delegation-keys \
    --name <storage-account> \
    --resource-group <resource-group>
```

Both the user delegation key and Azure role assignments are cached by Azure Storage, so there may be a delay between when you initiate the process of revocation and when an existing user delegation SAS becomes invalid.

metadata.title: Create a user delegation SAS for a container or blob with the Azure CLI

content:
### ‚úÖ Goal

Restore the *latest version* of every object under:

```
s3://invent-teknosa-datastore/parquet/data-files/ProductUDA/
```

...so that they appear as current objects again.

### AWS CLI

### üîß Step-by-Step Solution (Using AWS CLI)

#### 1. List Latest Versions

Run this command to list the latest versions under that prefix:

```
aws s3api list-object-versions \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --prefix parquet/data-files/ProductUDA/ \
  --query 'Versions[?IsLatest==`true`]' \
  --output json > latest_versions.json
```

#### 2. Filter Out the Delete Markers (Optional but Recommended)

```
aws s3api list-object-versions \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --prefix parquet/data-files/ProductUDA/ \
  --query 'DeleteMarkers[?IsLatest==`true`]' \
  --output json > delete_markers.json
```

To make the files "live" again, you need to remove these delete markers.

---

#### 3. Delete the Delete Markers (Undo Deletion)

in, you need to remove these delete markers.

---

#### 3. Delete the Delete Markers (Undo Deletion)

Loop through the `delete_markers.json` and delete them like this:

```
aws s3api delete-object \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --key <object-key> \
  --version-id <delete-marker-version-id>
```

This effectively restores the most recent version of that object as the current version.

---

#### 4. Re-copy Latest Versions (Optional Clean-up)

If you want to ensure all objects under `ProductUDA/` are re-uploaded as standard (current) versions (e.g., no version history, just fresh uploads), you can re-copy them:

```
aws s3api copy-object \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --copy-source invent-teknosa-datastore/<key>?versionId=<version-id> \
  --key <key>
```

You can loop over the `latest_versions.json` file to do this in bulk.

---

- List latest versions
- Remove delete markers
- Copy objects to restore current versionüîß Step-by-Step Solution (Using AWS CLI) 1. List Latest Versions Run this command to list the latest versions under that prefix:aws s3api list-object-versions \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --prefix parquet/data-files/ProductUDA/ \
  --query 'Versions[?IsLatest==`true`]' \
  --output json > latest_versions.json2. Filter Out the Delete Markers (Optional but Recommended) aws s3api list-object-versions \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --prefix parquet/data-files/ProductUDA/ \
  --query 'DeleteMarkers[?IsLatest==`true`]' \
  --output json > delete_markers.jsonTo make the files "live" again, you need to remove these delete markers.3. Delete the Delete Markers (Undo Deletion) Loop through the delete_markers.json and delete them like this:aws s3api delete-object \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --key <object-key> \

hem like this:aws s3api delete-object \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --key <object-key> \
  --version-id <delete-marker-version-id>This effectively restores the most recent version of that object as the current version.4. Re-copy Latest Versions (Optional Clean-up) If you want to ensure all objects under ProductUDA/ are re-uploaded as standard (current) versions (e.g., no version history, just fresh uploads), you can re-copy them:aws s3api copy-object \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --copy-source invent-teknosa-datastore/<key>?versionId=<version-id> \
  --key <key>You can loop over the latest_versions.json file to do this in bulk.

---

### ‚úÖ Step-by-Step Recovery

#### 1. List Delete Markers

Run this command to extract the latest delete markers:

```
aws s3api list-object-versions \
  --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
  --prefix parquet/data-files/ProductUDA/ \
  --query 'DeleteMarkers[?IsLatest==`true`]' \
  --output json > delete_markers.json
```

oductUDA/ \
  --query 'DeleteMarkers[?IsLatest==`true`]' \
  --output json > delete_markers.json
```

Check the contents:

```
cat delete_markers.json
```

You should see output like this:

```
[
  {
    "Key": "parquet/data-files/ProductUDA/file1.parquet",
    "VersionId": "XYZ123",
    "IsLatest": true,
    ...
  },
  ...
]
```

---

#### 2. Delete Those Delete Markers (Restore Files)

You can run the following shell script to remove each delete marker and restore the file:

```
#!/bin/bash

INPUT="delete_markers.json"

for row in $(jq -c '.[]' $INPUT); do
  KEY=$(echo $row | jq -r '.Key')
  VERSION_ID=$(echo $row | jq -r '.VersionId')

  echo "Restoring $KEY (deleting delete marker $VERSION_ID)"
  aws s3api delete-object \
    --bucket invent-teknosa-datastore \
    --key "$KEY" \
    --version-id "$VERSION_ID"
done

```

Save it as `restore_ProductUDA.sh`, make it executable:

```
chmod +x restore_ProductUDA.sh
./restore_ProductUDA.sh
```

---

### üß™ Final Validation

utable:

```
chmod +x restore_ProductUDA.sh
./restore_ProductUDA.sh
```

---

### üß™ Final Validation

Once you‚Äôve deleted the delete markers:

```bash
aws s3 ls s3://invent-teknosa-datastore/parquet/data-files/ProductUDA/ --recursive
```

You should now see the folder and all restored files listed.

## Problem

- Idle Airflow workloads left running by feature branchesThere are ~50 nodes and ~860 pods, which contains unnecessary and unmaintained workload
- No failed job cleaner.
- Each airflow scheduler (85 pieces) has 2 replicas.
- There are problems in prometheus-server0 and prometheus-prometheus-node-exporter-qczgf

## Action/Result

Currently, 26 nodes, and 450 pods.

Cost ‚Üì from $600 ‚Üí $280 / day (-55%)

## Next Steps

tion/Result

Currently, 26 nodes, and 450 pods.

Cost ‚Üì from $600 ‚Üí $280 / day (-55%)

## Next Steps

1. Automating cleanup 1‚Äî branch close ‚Üí namespace+identity delete
2. Automating cleanup 2‚Äî If there is no Scheduler activity for 7 days, then set replicas to 0 and keep ‚ÄúPersistent Volume‚Äù. No activity for 14 Days, delete NS.
3. Start/Stop ‚Üí Basically, when there is no development, Developers should be able to stop the workload.
4. Setting ownership labels, so each namespace has an expiry date and ownerExclude ‚ÄúLong Running Runs‚Äù
5. Adding Slack alerts to warn users before idle workloads are stopped
6. Separating branch types ‚Äî so Databricks-only branches don‚Äôt trigger K8s deployments‚ÄùDatabricks branches use the same naming conventions.
7. Follow-up Memory:112 Node pool utility.Since Rocket-pandas is using Azure Batch, no need to spin up a node. ‚Üí
